aBATRx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Could not find foraging movement literature specific to H. Gratiosa however, Johnson & Semlitsch (2003) identified movement fo H. Versicolor between 200m & 60m from breeding to terrestrial foraging, but predominately foraged within 15m of pools.  They recommend maintaining a 60m buffer to ensure population integrity.  So applied a more liberal buffer for H. gratiosa based on this paper. Amy Silvano 26jan07

Added fresh water mapunit. Steve Williams 25jan08

references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B05LAN01USGP: Lannoo, M. 2005. M. Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA (2005), p. 1094
references.B91TER01NCUS: Terwilliger, K. 1991. Virginia's endangered species. McDonald and Woodward Publishing Co., Blacksburg, VA. 170 pp.
references.B75CON01NAUS: Conant, R. 1975. A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern and Central North America. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xvii + 429 pp.
references.B13GRE01USGP: Green, D.M., L.A. Weir, G.S. Casper, and M.J. Lannoo. 2013.  North American Amphibians: Distribution and Diversity.  University of California Press. Berkeley, California. 340 pp.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.A03JOH01SEGP: Jarrett R. Johnson, Raymond D. Semlitsch . Defining core habitat of local populations of the gray treefrog ( Hyla versicolor) based on choice of oviposition site. Oecologia, Volume 137, Number 2 (October 2003), pp. 205-210, <http://ejournals.ebsco.com/direct.asp?ArticleID=2FG55BPRK51DUA0FAJ22
references.W15NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2015. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B13DOD01USGP: Dodd, C.K. 2013. Frogs of the United States and Canada.  The Johns Hopkins University Press. 982 Pp.
references.A91MIT01NAUS: Mitchell, J. C. 1991. Amphibians and reptiles. Pages 411-76 in K. Terwilliger (coordinator). Virginia's Endangered Species:Proceedings of a Symposium. McDonald and Woodward Publishing Company, Blacksburg, Virginia.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.A03JOH02SEGP: Johnson, J. R., and R. D. Semlitsch. 2003. Defining core habitat of local populations of the gray treefrog (Hyla versicolor) based on choice of oviposition site. Oecologia 137:205-210.
references.A83PER01NAUS: Perrill, S. A., and R. E. Daniel. 1983. Multiple egg clutches in HYLA REGILLA, H. CINEREA, and H. GRATIOSA. Copeia 1983:513-516.
references.A82CAL01NAUS: Caldwell, J. P. 1982. Hyla gratiosa. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 298.1-298.2.
references.W14HAM14USGP: Hammerson, G. Hyla gratiosa. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.3. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 10 May 2015.
references.B75MOU01NAUS: Mount, R. H. 1975. The Reptiles and Amphibians of Alabama. Auburn University Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn, Alabama. vii + 347 pp.
references.A52NEI04SEGP: Neill, W.T., 1952. Burrowing Habits of Hyla-Gratiosa. Copeia (3) 1952

habitat_description:
During hot and dry weather, the barking tree frog may take shelter in vegetation, under roots, and grass clumps. Its main range is the Coastal Plain in south Florida, east Louisiana, and North Carolina. Other minor localities include Delaware, Maryland, southwest Kentucky, and Tennessee (Conant and Collins 1998). Abundance in their range where are considered rare may be inaccurate due to presence of barking tree frogs only after heavy rains (Lannoo 2005).

Habitat for breeding includes ephemeral ponds, acid bogs, semi and permanent ponds, cypress ponds, flooded sand pits, sinkhole ponds, hammock wetlands, Carolina bays, corn fields, and backwaters of streams (Lannoo 2005). Individuals can be found in shrubs, trees, or buried into damp sand under logs or grass tussocks (Murphy 1994 in Lannoo 2005).
